repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - Sustainable Coastal Tourism
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Sustainable Coastal Tourism
            Development Project for Morocco had the following ratings:
            the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely,
            the institutional development impact was substantial, and
            the Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            The lessons learned indicate that for a public-private
            sector partnership to succeed, particularly in Morocco, a
            strong and unwavering Government commitment and broad
            political support is critical. Learning and Innovation Loans
            (LILs) can be highly effective if they support a
            reform-minded public agency and use Bank support to design
            an innovative implementation framework to deliver effective
            outputs. Quality private sector investments will be
            attracted only if the transactions are well structured and
            there is a transparent and competitive bidding process.
            Structuring and concluding a transaction leading to a viable
            public-private partnership should involve learning by doing.
            The project demonstrated the importance of the support of
            rear-line public agencies to the front-line negotiating
            agency in order for the private sector to feel confident
            that Government will deliver on its commitments.

repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - Sustainable Coastal Tourism
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Sustainable Coastal
            Tourism Development Project is to propose, test, and
            evaluate the institutional framework and contractual
            procedures for managing public-private partnerships that are
            best suited for integrated and sustainable development of
            coastal sites in the Moroccan context. The components
            include: 1) preparation of indicative development plans, and
            pre-feasibility studies for three new coastal tourism
            development sites. A conceptual plan for the whole tourism
            development site will be produced, in addition to indicative
            development plans, and pre-feasibility studies for the
            selected tourism development unit, and for the selection of
            private master developers; 2) technical assistance (TA) to
            the Department of Development and Investment of the Ministry
            of Tourism, namely for the supervision, and management of
            the three new coastal tourism development sites, in addition
            to three on-going development sites. TA will help prepare
            indicative development plans, evaluate the private
            developers proposals, and prepare preliminary contract
            agreements; and 3) technical assistance to implement the new
            institutional framework for tourism sites development.
